<dd><a href="/wiki/Glucose" title="Glucose">C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>12</sub>O<sub>6</sub></a> + H<sub>2</sub>O + O<sub>2</sub> → <a href="/wiki/Gluconic_acid" title="Gluconic acid">C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>12</sub>O<sub>7</sub></a> + <a href="/wiki/Hydrogen_peroxide" title="Hydrogen peroxide">H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub></a> (glucose oxidase reaction)
</dd>
</dl>
<p>When honey is used topically (as, for example, a wound dressing), hydrogen peroxide is produced by dilution of the honey with body fluids. As a result, hydrogen peroxide is released slowly and acts as an antibacterial.<sup id="cite_ref-pmid21479349_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pmid21479349-89">[89]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Use_for_diabetic_ulcers">Use for diabetic ulcers</span></h3>
<p>Topical honey has been used successfully in a comprehensive treatment of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chronic_wound&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chronic wound (page does not exist)">diabetic ulcers</a> when the patient cannot use topical antibiotics.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Acidity">Acidity</span></h3>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/PH" title="PH">pH</a> of honey is commonly between 3.2 and 4.5.<sup id="cite_ref-antimicrobial_84-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-antimicrobial-84">[84]</a></sup> This relatively acidic pH level prevents the growth of many bacteria.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Methylglyoxal">Methylglyoxal</span></h3>
<p>The nonperoxide antibiotic activity is due to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Methylglyoxal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Methylglyoxal (page does not exist)">methylglyoxal</a> (MGO) and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bee_defensin-1&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bee defensin-1 (page does not exist)">bee defensin-1</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup> Most honeys contain very low levels of MGO, but manuka honey contains very high levels. The presence of the synergist in manuka honey more than doubles MGO antibacterial activity.<sup id="cite_ref-manuka_85-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-manuka-85">[85]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nutraceutical_effects">Nutraceutical effects</span></h3>
<p>Antioxidants in honey have even been associated with reducing the damage done to the colon in <a href="/wiki/Colitis" title="Colitis">colitis</a> in a study involving administering honey <a href="/wiki/Enemas" title="Enemas" class="mw-redirect">enemas</a> to rats.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup> Such claims are consistent with its use in many traditions of <a href="/wiki/Folk_medicine" title="Folk medicine">folk medicine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Use_for_sore_throats_and_coughs">Use for sore throats and coughs</span></h3>
<p>Honey has also been used for centuries as a treatment for sore throats and coughs and, according to recent research, may be an effective soothing agent for coughs.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_medical_applications">Other medical applications</span></h3>
<p>Unfiltered, pasteurized honey is widely believed to alleviate allergies, though neither commercially filtered nor raw honey was shown to be more effective than <a href="/wiki/Placebo" title="Placebo">placebo</a> in a controlled study of 36 participants with <a href="/wiki/Allergic_conjunctivitis" title="Allergic conjunctivitis">ocular allergies</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> Nearly 1 in 3 of the volunteers dropped out of the study because they couldn't tolerate eating one tablespoon of honey every day due to the overly sweet taste.<sup id="cite_ref-More.2C_MD_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-More.2C_MD-96">[96]</a></sup> The official conclusion: "This study does not confirm the widely held belief that honey relieves the symptoms of allergic rhinoconjunctivitis." A more recent study has shown pollen collected by bees to exert an antiallergenic effect, mediated by an inhibition of IgE immunoglobulin binding to <a href="/wiki/Mast_cells" title="Mast cells" class="mw-redirect">mast cells</a>. This inhibited mast cell degranulation and thus reduced allergic reaction.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup> The risk of experiencing <a href="/wiki/Anaphylaxis" title="Anaphylaxis">anaphylaxis</a> as an immune system reaction may outweigh any potential allergy relief.<sup id="cite_ref-More.2C_MD_96-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-More.2C_MD-96">[96]</a></sup>
</p><p>A review in the Cochrane Library suggests honey could reduce the time it takes for a mild burn to heal — up to four days sooner in some cases. The review included 19 studies with 2,554 participants. Although the honey treatment healed mild burns faster than traditional dressings did, the author recommends viewing the findings with caution, since a single research centre performed all of the burn studies.<sup id="cite_ref-Jull_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jull-98">[98]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Health_hazards">Health hazards</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Botulism">Botulism</span></h3>
<p>Because of the natural presence of <a href="/wiki/Clostridium_botulinum" title="Clostridium botulinum">botulinum</a> <a href="/wiki/Endospore" title="Endospore">endospores</a> in honey,<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup> children under one year of age should not be given honey. The more-developed digestive system of older children and adults generally destroys the spores. Infants, however, can contract <a href="/wiki/Botulism" title="Botulism">botulism</a> from honey.<sup id="cite_ref-NHB_botulism_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NHB_botulism-100">[100]</a></sup> Medical grade honey can be treated with gamma radiation to reduce the risk of botulinum spores being present.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup> Gamma radiation evidently does not affect honey's antibacterial activity, whether or not the particular honey's antibacterial activity is dependent upon peroxide generation.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup>
</p><p>Infantile botulism shows geographical variation. In the UK, only six cases have been reported between 1976 and 2006,<sup id="cite_ref-FSA_botulism_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FSA_botulism-103">[103]</a></sup> yet the U.S. has much higher rates: 1.9 per 100,000 live births, 47.2% of which are in California.<sup id="cite_ref-CdcBotulism_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CdcBotulism-104">[104]</a></sup> While the risk honey poses to infant health is small, it is recommended not to take the risk.<sup id="cite_ref-ENY128_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ENY128-105">[105]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Toxic_honey">Toxic honey</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Honey produced from flowers of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Oleander&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oleander (page does not exist)">oleanders</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rhododendron" title="Rhododendron">rhododendrons</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kalmia_latifolia" title="Kalmia latifolia">mountain laurels</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sheep_laurel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sheep laurel (page does not exist)">sheep laurel</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Azalea" title="Azalea">azaleas</a> may cause <a href="/wiki/Grayanotoxin" title="Grayanotoxin">honey intoxication</a>. Symptoms include dizziness, weakness, excessive perspiration, nausea, and vomiting. Less commonly, low blood pressure, shock, heart rhythm irregularities, and convulsions may occur, with rare cases resulting in death. Honey intoxication is more likely when using "natural" unprocessed honey and honey from farmers who may have a small number of hives. Commercial processing, with pooling of honey from numerous sources, is thought to dilute any toxins.<sup id="cite_ref-FDA_106-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FDA-106">[106]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="New_Zealand">New Zealand</span></h4>
<p>Toxic honey may also result when bees are proximate to <a href="/wiki/Tutu_(plant)" title="Tutu (plant)">tutu</a> bushes (<i>Coriaria arborea</i>) and the vine hopper insect (<i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Scolypopa_australis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scolypopa australis (page does not exist)">Scolypopa australis</a></i>). Both are found throughout New Zealand. Bees gather honeydew produced by the vine hopper insects feeding on the tutu plant. This introduces the poison <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tutin_(toxin)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tutin (toxin) (page does not exist)">tutin</a> into honey.<sup id="cite_ref-NBA_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NBA-107">[107]</a></sup> Only a few areas in New Zealand (Coromandel Peninsula, Eastern Bay of Plenty and the Marlborough Sound) frequently produce toxic honey. Symptoms of tutin poisoning include vomiting, delirium, giddiness, increased excitability, stupor, coma, and violent convulsions. To reduce the risk of tutin poisoning, humans should not eat honey taken from feral hives in the risk areas of New Zealand. Since December 2001, New Zealand beekeepers have been required to reduce the risk of producing toxic honey by closely monitoring tutu, vine hopper, and foraging conditions within <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of their apiary.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Honey-producing_and_consuming_countries">Honey-producing and consuming countries</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:2005honey_(natural).PNG" title="File:2005honey (natural).PNG">File:2005honey (natural).PNG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">2005 Honey-producing countries</div></div></div>
<table class="wikitable" style="float:right; margin: 0 0 0.5em 1em">
<caption> Top Five Natural Honey Producing Countries <br />(in metric tons)
</caption>
<tr>
<th>Rank
</th>
<th>Country
</th>
<th>2009
</th>
<th>2010
</th>
<th>2011
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td> 1 </td>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data China (page does not exist)">Template:Country data China</a> </td>
<td> 407,367 </td>
<td> 409,149 </td>
<td> 446,089
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 2 </td>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Turkey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Turkey (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Turkey</a> </td>
<td> 82,003 </td>
<td> 81,115 </td>
<td> 94,245
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 3 </td>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Ukraine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Ukraine (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Ukraine</a> </td>
<td> 74,100 </td>
<td> 70,900 </td>
<td> 70,300
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 4 </td>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data United States (page does not exist)">Template:Country data United States</a> </td>
<td> 66,413 </td>
<td> 80,042 </td>
<td> 67,294
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 5 </td>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Russia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Russia (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Russia</a> </td>
<td> 53,598 </td>
<td> 51,535 </td>
<td> 60,010
</td></tr>
<tr bgcolor="#CCCCCC">
<td> — </td>
<td> <i><a href="/wiki/World" title="World">World</a></i> </td>
<td> 1,199,943 </td>
<td> 1,212,586 </td>
<td> 1,282,102
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="5"> <center> <i>Source: <a href="/w/index.php?title=FAO&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="FAO (page does not exist)">UN Food &amp; Agriculture Organization</a></i> <sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup>
</td></tr></table>
<p>In 2012, <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Turkey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Turkey (page does not exist)">Turkey</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> were the top producers of natural honey.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup>
</p><p>Significant regional producers of honey include <a href="/wiki/United_States_of_America" title="United States of America" class="mw-redirect">United States of America</a> (ranked fourth worldwide) and <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a> (ranked fifth worldwide).
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mexico (page does not exist)">Mexico</a> is also an important producer of honey, providing more than 4% of the world's supply.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup> Much of this (about one-third) comes from the <a href="/wiki/Yucat%C3%A1n_Peninsula" title="Yucatán Peninsula">Yucatán Peninsula</a>. Honey production began there when the <i>Apis mellifera</i> and the <i>A. mellifera ligustica</i> were introduced there early in the 20th century. Most of Mexico's Yucatán producers are small, family operations who use original traditional techniques, moving hives to take advantage of the various tropical and subtropical flowers.<sup id="cite_ref-MexDes_111-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MexDes-111">[111]</a></sup>
</p><p>Honey is also one of the gourmet products of the French island of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Corsica&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Corsica (page does not exist)">Corsica</a>. Corsican honey is certified as to its origin (<i><a href="/wiki/Appellation_d%27origine_contr%C3%B4l%C3%A9e" title="Appellation d'origine contrôlée">Appellation d'origine contrôlée</a></i>) just as are French wines, like Champagne.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup>
</p><p>Honey consumption per capita per year exceeds one kilogram in some countries like Austria, Germany and Switzerland.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Gallery_of_honey_harvesting">Gallery of honey harvesting</span></h2>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional">
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 195px"><div style="width: 195px">

</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 195px"><div style="width: 195px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">Smoker.jpg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Smoking the hive
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>

<p>Using a blower to remove bees from honey prior to removal to honey house
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 195px"><div style="width: 195px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">Protection.jpg</div>

</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>

<p>A capped honey super frame
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>

</p>

			</div>
		</div></li>
</ul>
